response.apiMessage: This XML was provided by Springer Nature

title-group.article-title: Synthesis and applications of thieno[3,4-c]pyrrole-4,6-dione based linear to star-burst novel D–A conjugated oligomers for organic photovoltaics

institution-wrap.institution: National Institute of Science and Technology
Veer Surendra Sai University of Technology (VSSUT)
North Eastern Regional Institute of Science and Technology

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: A series of well-defined donor–acceptor (D–A) conjugated oligomers incorporating thieno[3,4-c]pyrrole-4,6-dione (TPD) acceptor and two symmetrical thiophene units as donor π-bridge along the axes of triphenyl amine core have been synthesized and explored in bulk heterojunction (BHJ) solar cells. Under illumination with AM 1.5 white light (100 mW/cm2), the performance of BHJ photovoltaic devices with an active layer of an electron-donor oligomeric material (TPATP1, TPATP2 or TPATP3) blended with an electron acceptor {[6,6]-phenyl-C61-butyric acid methyl ester (PC61BM) or [6,6]-phenyl-C71-butyric acid methyl ester (PC71BM) at various weight ratios has been investigated. The photovoltaic device containing the donor TPATP1 and the acceptor PC71BM at a 1:3 weight ratio exhibited the best efficiency of 1.87% with an open circuit voltage (Voc) of 0.86 V, short circuit current (Jsc) of 6.59 mA/cm2, and a fill factor (FF) of 33%. These results demonstrate that irrespective of conjugation length, tuning of materials with efficient donor and acceptor materials can enhance the optical, electrochemical and eventually the power conversion efficiency (PCE) values of BHJ solar cells. Furthermore oligomers containing TPD acceptor in different structural form have different unique contribution towards photovoltaic properties.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Organic photovoltaics have attracted remarkable interest as an alternate sustainable and renewable source of energy over the conventional silicon based solar cell, due to their low manufacturing costs, low environmental impact during manufacturing and mechanical flexibility which is compatible with foldable or rollable substrates [1–4]. Over a decade, π-conjugated D–A small molecules dragged significant attention of scientific community owing it’s notable advantages including easier purification, control in molecular weight distribution, and better batch-to-batch reproducibility. Furthermore, small molecule based organic photovoltaics has been made a tremendous progress accompanied by a rapid increase in energy conversion efficiencies [5–14].

Low-band-gap organic materials can potentially increase the light harvesting from solar spectrum due to its extended conjugation and panchromatic absorption. One approach of designing these materials is the use of alternating electron-rich (donor) and electron-poor (acceptor) units giving rise to a material with a low-energy absorption band that is generally ascribed to a charge transfer band. In addition the TPD moiety imparts high optical density while its electron affinity lowers frontier energy levels to complement those of PC61/71BM. Concurrently, the differential architects of the oligomers from linear to starburst shape D–A extension along the axes of hole transporting triphenyl amine core with thiophene π-bridge contributes enhanced electron transfer and high hole mobility [15, 16]. The TPD–thiophene motif also provides broader absorption spectra so as to increase the light harvesting efficiency. Hence structural configuration having TPD acceptor was found as promising acceptor moiety and have tunable optical, electrochemical properties to be used in BHJ solar cells [17–20].

Herein we report the synthesis and characterization of a series of novel low band-gap D–A oligomeric semiconductors TPATP1, TPATP2 and TPATP3 (shown in Fig. 1) based on TPD acceptor which contain ethylhexyl substituent and two symmetric oligo thiophene donors along the triphenyl arms. The presence of TPD acceptor at different structural configuration i.e., from linear to star shape tuned the optical and electrochemical properties. BHJ photovoltaic devices were fabricated by using small molecules (TPATP1, TPATP2 and TPATP3) as the donor and PC61/71BM as the acceptor. The optimized photovoltaic devices revealed that the device containing blend of TPATP1 and PC71BM with 1:3 weight ratio, having spin 3000 rpm have the PCE of 1.87%, with Voc = 0.86 V, Jsc = 6.59 mA/cm2, and a FF = 33% under simulated AM 1.5 illumination (100 mW/cm2). Furthermore the device showed external quantum efficiency (EQE) of 32% at wavelength 460 nm and the photo response extended up to 700 nm.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: The various chemicals and solvents used were reagent grades and purchased from ACROS, Aldrich, Fluka, and TCI. Toluene, ether and tetrahydrofuran (THF) were distilled over Na/benzophenone. CHCl3 was purified by refluxing over CaH2 followed by distillation. The other solvents if not specified were deoxygenated through N2 purging for 1 h prior to their use.

sec.title: Measurements and characterization
sec.p: 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded in Varian Unity 300 MHz spectrometer. HERAEUS CHN-OS RAPID elemental analyzer, Shimadzu was used for elemental analyses. Optical absorption studies are being carried out at 300 K using a dual beam UV–Vis spectrophotometer, Shimazu UV-1800 in dilute dichlorobenzene (DCB) solutions or in solid films that have been spin-coated onto glass substrate in same solution at a concentration of 10 mg/mL. BAS 100 electrochemical analyzer has been used to measure the cyclic voltammetry (CV) at room temperature using a standard three-electrode electrochemical cell. For CV measurement A solution of 0.1 M tetrabutylammonium hexafluorophosphate (TBAPF6) in MeCN purged with nitrogen for 30 s, and a scanning rate of 100 mV/s has been taken. In each case, a carbon working electrode coated with a thin layer of the oligomer film, a platinum wire as the counter electrode, and a silver wire as the quasi-reference electrode were used, and Ag/AgCl (3 M NaCl) electrode was served as a reference electrode. The redox couple of ferrocene/ferrocenium ion (Fc/Fc+) was used as an external standard. The corresponding energy levels of the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) were calculated using the values of Eox/onset and Ered/onset determined from CV measurement. The solid films were drop-casted films at a similar thickness from DCB solutions (ca. 5 mg/mL) for all the potentials. The onset potentials were determined from the intersections of two tangents drawn at the rising currents and background currents of the CV measurements.

sec.title: Fabrication of organic solar cells (OSCs)
sec.p:
The BHJ solar cell devices were fabricated by blending active layer of small molecules (TPATP1, TPATP2 and TPATP3) with PC61BM/PC71BM in solid films, which were sandwiched between a transparent indium tin oxide (ITO) anode and Ca/Al as a cathode. Prior to fabrication ITO-coated glass substrates (1.5 × 1.5 cm2) were ultrasonically cleaned in detergent, deionized water, acetone, and isopropyl alcohol sequentially followed by UV ozone treatment of the substrates for 20 min. The ITO surface was then spin-coated with a layer of poly(ethylene dioxythiophene):polystyrenesulfonate (PEDOT:PSS) (thickness ca. 30 nm) followed by heat treatment for 1 h at 130 °C. The substrates were transferred to a N2-filled glove-box and the active layer was deposited on top of the PEDOT:PSS layer through spin coating (ca. 2500 rpm, 60 s) of a small molecule (TPATP1, TPATP2, TPATP3) blended with a PCBM (PC61BM or PC71BM) at a ratio of 1:1, 1:2, or 1:3 (w/w); the thickness of the active layer was typically maintained ca. 80 nm. Initially, the blended solutions were prepared by dissolving both small molecules and PCBM in DCB solution (10 mg/1 mL), followed by continuous stirring for 12 h at 50 °C. Finally, a Ca layer (30 nm) and an Al layer (100 nm) were thermally evaporated sequentially through a shadow mask at a pressure of less than 6 × 10−6 torr. The active area of each device was kept 0.12 cm2. All BHJ solar cell devices were prepared and characterized under ambient conditions. The properties of solar cells were measured inside a glove box under simulated AM 1.5G irradiation (100 mW/cm2) using a Xe lamp-based solar simulator (Thermal Oriel 1000 W). The EQE spectra were obtained under short-circuit conditions. The light source was a 450 W Xe lamp (Oriel Instrument, model 6266) equipped with a water-based IR filter (Oriel The light source was a 450 W Xe lamp (Oriel Instrument, Instrument, model 6123NS). The light output from the monochromator (Oriel Instrument, model 74100) was focused on the photovoltaic cell being tested. Fig. 1
Molecular structures of TPATP1 TPATP2 and TPATP3

sec.title: Synthesis and structural characterization
sec.p:
As shown in Scheme 1 Compounds 1, 3(a), 3(b), 3(c), 4(a), 4(b), and 4(c), were synthesized by known literature procedure [16, 17]. The controlled bromination in Compound 2 was carried through phase wise addition of NBS in chloroform [19, 20]. The oligomers TPATP1, TPATP2, TPATP3 were synthesized through Suzuki coupling reactions between 4(a) & 2, 4(b) & 2 and 4(c) & 2 respectively. The detailed synthetic procedures of some are as follows.Scheme 1
Synthetic procedures for TPATP1, TPATP2 and TPATP3

1-(5-bromothiophen-2-yl)-5-(2-ethylhexyl)-3-(thiophen-2-yl)-5H-thieno[3,4-c]pyrrole-4,6-dione (2):N-Bromosuccinimide (NBS, 2.07 g, 11.65 mmol) was added in portions to a solution of 1 (5 g, 11.65 mmol) in CHCl3 (100 mL) in a two-neck flask at 5 °C. The mixture was warmed to room temperature and stirred overnight. CH2Cl2 was added and then the solution was washed with brine. The organic phase was dried with anhydrous MgSO4 and the solvent evaporated under reduced pressure. The crude product was purified chromatographically (SiO2;hexane/EtOAc, 1:1) to yield a red solid (3.61 g, 61%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3), δ (ppm): 8.02 (d, J = 3.6 Hz, 1H),7.66(d, 4.2 Hz, 1H) 7.45 (d, J = 5.1 Hz, 1H), 7.14–7.12 (m, 2H), 3.55 (d, 7.2 Hz, 2H), 1.85–1.81 (m, 1H), 1.36–1.31 (m, 8H), 0.94–0.86 (m, 6H).

sec.title: TPATP1
sec.p: Mixture of compound 4a (0.36 g, 1.00 mmol), compound 2 (0.5 g, 1 mmol), and 2 M K2CO3 (359 mg, 2.6 mmol) were dissolved in 30 ml of toluene and ethanol (3:1) and degassed for 10 min, and then Pd(PPh3−) 4 (45 mg, 0.04 mmol) was added. The resulting mixture refluxed for 36 h. The solvent was removed in rotary evaporator and the product was extracted with dichloromethane with water wash followed by a little brine. The organic phase was dried with anhydrous MgSO4, and the solvent was removed under vacuum. Subsequently, the crude compound was purified by column chromatography (silica) using dichloromethane as an eluent and washed with methanol and hexane to yield black color solid (0.45 g, 68%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3), δ (ppm): 7.93 (d, J = 1.8 Hz, 2H), 7.40 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H), 7.34 (d, J = 3.9 Hz, 1H), 7.23–6.96 (m, 14H), 3.47 (d, J = 7.2 Hz, 2H), 1.8 (m, 1H), 1.30–1.17 (m, 8H). 0.87–0.80 (m, 6H). 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ 163.1, 148.4, 148.0,147.4, 141.8, 136.9, 136.1, 132.7, 131.5, 130.8, 130.0, 129.6, 128.7, 128.6, 128, 127.1, 127.0, 125.0, 123.7, 123.5, 123.2, 122.9, 120.4, 42.7, 38.4, 31.8, 30.8, 29.9, 28.8, 24.1, 23.2, 22.8, 14.3, 10.7. MS (FAB): m/z [M+] 671; calcd m/z [M+] 672.19. Anal. Calcd for C40H36N2O2S3: C, 71.39; H, 5.39; N, 4.16 Found: C, 71.89; H, 5.69; N, 4.20.

sec.title: Optical properties
sec.p:
Optical properties were investigated by measuring the absorption spectra of the D–π–A molecules (TPATP1, TPATP2 and TPATP3) in DCB solutions (Fig. 2a) as well as in the solid films (Fig. 2b) and the relevant data are listed in Table 1. In solution, TPATP1 exhibited absorption maxima at, 445 nm, TPATP2 at 460 nm and TPATP3 at 471 nm. In addition all the molecules extended their absorption spectra up to 550 nm which is attributed to the intramolecular charge transfer (ICT) transitions between their donor cores and the acceptor propellants [21]. Furthermore the spectra of the solid films, the absorption maxima and the absorption onset of all the small molecules (TPATP1, TPATP2 and TPATP3) were bathochromically shifted significantly relative to those in solutions. These bathochromic shifts in solid films were attributed to the intermolecular interactions in the solid films. The absorption maxima in both solutions and solid films were increased from TPATP1 to TPATP3 chronologically which were ascribed to the increase in conjugations with increase in D–A arms from TPATP1 to TPATP3. However in due course the increase in D–A arms decreased the net solubility of the molecule and consequently reflected as poor photocurrent densities in the photovoltaic devices [22].Fig. 2
UV–Vis spectra of TPATP1 TPATP2 and TPATP3 in (a) dilute dichlorobenzene solutions and (b) solid filmsTable 1

sec.title: Electrochemical properties
sec.p:
The electronic structures of D–π–A small molecules TPATP1, TPATP2 and TPATP3 including the HOMO and LUMO levels were investigated by the cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements in solid films with Ag/AgCl as a reference electrode, calibrated by ferrocene (E1/2(ferrocene) = 0.45 mV vs. Ag/AgCl). The HOMO and LUMO levels were calculated by the onset oxidation and reduction potentials from the reference energy level of ferrocene (4.8 eV below the vacuum level) according to the following equation: [23] EHOMO/LUMO = [− (Eonset − 0.45) − 4.8] eV and the results are summarized in Fig. 3 and Table 2. The HOMO/LUMO found for TPATP1, TPATP2 and TPATP3 were − 5.19/− 3.34, − 5.20/− 3.35, − 5.27/− 3.50 respectively. Thus the bandgap were 1.85, 1.85 and 1.70 eV for TPATP1, TPATP2 and TPATP3 correspondingly and the data were steady with the no of acceptor branches in the star-shaped molecules. In addition, the band gaps found were in the desirable range to be utilized in the organic photovoltaic applications [24]. The similar Homo energy levels can be ascribed as the identical core and repeating arms of the molecules. Furthermore the LUMO energy levels of small molecules TPATP1, TPATP2 and TPATP3 (− 3.34, − 3.35 and − 3.50) are positioned 0.3 eV above the LUMO level of PC61BM/PC71BM acceptor which ensures energetically favorable levels for electron transfer [25].Fig. 3
Cyclic voltammograms of TPATP1 TPATP2 and TPATP3 films (drop cast) on platinum electrode measured in 0.1 M ((TBA)PF6) acetonitrile solutions at a scan rate of 100 mV/sTable 2

sec.title: Photovoltaic properties
sec.p:
To demonstrate the potential application of the D–A conjugated small molecules (TPATP1, TPATP2 and TPATP3) in organic photovoltaics, BHJ organic photovoltaic devices have been fabricated with the configuration ITO/PEDOT:PSS (30 nm)/TPATP1, TPATP2 or TPATP3:PC61BM/PC71BM blend (ca. 80 nm)/Ca (30 nm)/Al (100 nm). The active layers of the devices were spin coated (3000 rpm) from 1,2-dichlorobenzene solutions containing a small molecules and PC61BM/PC71BM at 1:3 (w/w). Owing to its broader absorption and higher absorption coefficients in the region from 440 to 530 the small molecules (TPATP1, TPATP2 or TPATP3) were blended with PC71BM at 1:3 (w/w). Later the best performing active layer (TPATP1) was blended with PC71BM using various weight ratios (1:1,1:2,1:3, and 1:4) which could complement the small molecule absorption valley better than PC61BM [26]. All the devices were tested under simulated air mass coefficient AM 1.5 G illumination (100 mW cm−2) and the data are summarized in Tables 3 and 4. The photovoltaic device containing the donor TPATP1 and the acceptor PC61BM (1:3 weight ratio) exhibited the best power conversion efficiency among the three small molecules with PCE of 0.89% open circuit voltage of 0.76 V, a short circuit current density of 3.47 mA cm−2, and a fill factor of 34.7%. It has been demonstrated that the Voc value in BHJ solar cells is linearly dependent on the difference between the HOMO level of p-type oligomer and the LUMO level of an n-type PCBM [27]. However, as shown in Fig. 4 and Table 3 the Voc value of the cell device based on TPATP1, TPATP2 and TPATP3 (HOMO energy level: − 5.19, − 5.20, − 5.27) were 0.76 V, 0.47 V, 0.50 V respectively. In fact, this discrepancy in results indicated that Voc is correlated not only to the difference between the HOMO of the donor and the LUMO of the acceptor but also the electronic properties of the donor, acceptor, and the D/A interface, charge recombination, degree of phase-separation between the components in the blend, the photo induced dipole formed at the interface due to the charge transfer, and the surface morphology of the active layers of small molecule:PCBM [28]. All these factors must be taken into account, which can alter expected Voc value significantly. The increasing D–A arms in triphenyl core restricted the net Jsc which may be attributed to its decreasing solubility decreased the compatibility with PC61BM molecules in the films cast from the DCB solutions. Altogether the increase in D–A arms in triphenyl core (TPATP2 and TPATP3) decreased both the power conversion efficiency contributing parameters (Voc and Jsc) so as to decrease the PCE value (TPATP2: PCE = 0.34% and TPATP3: PCE = 0.32%) eventually (Table 3). In order to get the advantage of high absorption coefficient of PC71BM than PC61BM in absorption spectra, BHJ photovoltaic devices were made with small molecules (TPATP1, TPATP2 and TPATP3) as donor and PC71BM acceptor in the same ratio. As expected, the PCE values of all the small molecules increased significantly compare to the earlier PC61BM blended active layer. This is likely due to an increase in light harvesting by the acceptor materials. As shown in Fig. 4b and Table 3, though there is increase in absorption with increase in number of D–A propellants in triphenyl core but the lowest D–A propellant (TPATP1) has the highest PCE values (PCE = 1.87%), followed by TPATP2 and TPATP3 with PCE value of 1.45% and 1.08% respectively. The constraints in PCE values for the star-burst small molecules (TPATP2 and TPATP3) are due to the decrease in solubility with increase in star-burst conjugations. In addition there was formation of pinholes in the device by shrinking of the materials film which is attributed to the decrease in the solution density. The lower value of FF (30–35%), which restricted the overall PCE values, could be due to increase in series resistance. As the blending ratio between the organic molecule and PC71BM in active layer affects the device performance, we studied solar cell devices incorporating blending ratios ranging from 1:1 to 1:3 (TPATP1:PC71BM) and the data are enlisted in Table 4. As shown in Fig. 5 and Table 4, with the increase in the amount of TPATP1:PC71BM ratio from 1:1 to 1:2 and then to 1:3 in the active layer increased the Jsc from 2.75 to 5.44 and then to 6.59 respectively which is attributed to the phenomenon of sufficient number of electron and hole percolation pathways that were formed to allow more efficient charge separation [29]. The photovoltaic properties of TPATP1:PC71BM in different ratios further analyzed by the surface morphologies. As shown in the AFM picture (Fig. 6), the TPATP1:PC71BM with 1:3 ratios has the smoother surface with surface roughness 0.34 nm as that of 1:1 and 1:2 ratios with surface roughness 0.52 nm and 0.59 nm respectively. The higher roughness consequences a large-scale phase separation which decreases the diffusional escapes probability for mobile charge carriers, and hence increases recombination [30]. Thus the favorable morphology of the device containing TPATP1:PC71BM based device resulted the best PCE value of 1.87% with VOC of 0.86 V, Jsc of 6.59 mA and FF of 33%. In fact owing to the low and unequal proportion of hole and electron mobilities, the quality of the small molecule BHJ solar cells are comparably poor. Figure 7 presents the EQE spectra of the devices (TPATP1, TPATP2, TPATP3/PC71BM) in 1:3 weight ratios. The small molecule TPATP1 got the maximum EQE of 32% where as TPATP2, TPATP3 have EQE around 28% in between 400 to 700 nm and showed a great consistency with their PCE values.Table 3

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: We designed three well-defined linear to starburst, TPD based D–π–A conjugated small molecules and the optical, electrochemical and photovoltaic properties have been studied. The photovoltaic device containing the donor TPATP1 and the acceptor PC71BM at a 1:3 weight ratio exhibited the best open circuit voltage of 0.86 V, Jsc of 6.59 mA and FF of 33% with a power conversion efficiency of 1.87%. Furthermore the EQE spectra of the best device (TPATP-1/PC71BM in 1:3 weight ratios) got a maximum EQE of 32%. Though the PCE values decreased with increase in D–A arms in starburst small molecules, however the optical and electrochemical results provides a great approach to engineer starburst molecules to increase the solubility and thus to increase the solar cell efficiencies eventually.

ack.title: Acknowledgement
ack.p: The financial supports of this project provided by the Department of Chemistry, the National Institute of Science and Technology, Berhampur, Odisha, are greatly acknowledged.

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: Authors declare no conflict of interest for any part of the work reported in this article.
